{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3620919,"name":"Rod","username":"Weldingrod1","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/weldingrod1/{size}/162109_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-11T19:16:21.065Z","cooked":"

Since I’ve always wondered about the semi-mythical battery break in period, I thought I’d blow $50 and answer the question!

Starting out, I took a battery we inherited from the World Championship. It was bought new and only used for the competition. So, relatively few cycles on it. I ran it through 18 discharge cycles at 12 Amps (maximum for the tester I have on hand) and 11 Volt cutoff. Note that most of 5892’s testing is done at 10.5 Volt cutoff, but I chose this to minimize the impact of this scale of testing on the capacity of the battery.

There’s two data points that are oddly low. I really don’t know what’s up there! Other than that, there is a small downward trend across the testing, but its only 1.3% on the curve fit (with the two outliers removed)

I have just started testing a brand new Expert Power battery from Amazon, but I thought summer CD would be interested in seeing the testing results from a significant campaign

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2025-05-11T19:16:21.065Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":18,"reads":346,"readers_count":345,"score":344.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":501560,"topic_slug":"battery-break-in-testing","display_username":"Rod","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":12}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":46443,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/battery-break-in-testing/501560/1","custom_user_title":"Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":12}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":12,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3630456,"name":"Rod","username":"Weldingrod1","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/weldingrod1/{size}/162109_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-20T19:15:27.596Z","cooked":"

And NOW the good stuff!

I took a brand new Expert Power battery from Amazon. It arrived at 97% charge. Amazon.com: ExpertPower EXP12180 12V 18Ah Lead Acid Battery : Health & Household
EXP12180 12V 18Ah Lead Acid Battery

All testing was done at 12 Amp constant current, 11 Volt cutoff point.
Internal resistance includes 6AWG cable and Anderson SB50 connector. I used a FNIRSI Internal Resistance Voltage Tester, HRM-10. I fabricated a custom wiring harness with Kelvin connections soldered into the Anderson SB50 pins.

As we have been led to believe, the battery capacity increased. The first cycle added 2,230 mAhrs! The second added another 226 mAhr. After that the battery’s capacity dropped by 170 mAhrs per cycle, pretty evenly (I did a curve fit taking out the first data point).

I’m kind of surprised that I didn’t see this level of steady degradation on the MK battery; this one lost 11 mAhrs per cycle.

Based on this, I’m leaning away from buying more of these batteries…

On the break in cycle, it looks like one load cycle does most of it. Unfortunately I don’t have data on break in current vs battery capacity.

Maybe next season I will ask my electrical crew to pull this type of data!

Weldingrod1:

There’s two data points that are oddly low. I really don’t know what’s up there

It is possible that the battery was not fully charged. Ambient temperature may also cause some variation in the measured battery capacity.

We did a bunch of testing of our chargers last fall using the same battery capacity tester that you lent to us and that you are likely using for these tests. In some of these tests, we charged a battery on the same charging port of a particular 3-port charger. The battery was charged at least overnight since we were at the STEM Center only 3x each week. The same test was done with a second battery on a different brand of 3-port charger. We saw only around 2% variation in the battery capacity for each of the two batteries.

These tests were all done at our STEM Center where the temperature variation is relatively small over time.

The two low spots on the MK battery are even weirder knowing that the second battery’s testing was done with exactly the same set of hardware! About 40% of the cycles were charge to 100% / 0 Amps and test immediately, and the other 60% were overnight charges.

All of my charging was going to 100% / 0 Amps into the battery… Air conditioned house too!

I did similar testing on a Powersonic 18AH battery and found that it was as good as it was going to get by the 4th charge/discharge cycle.
